awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Unraveling the Convergent Origins of Secondary Palates in Amniotes
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Zachary S. Morris has been granted an NSF EAR postdoctoral fellowship to conduct research and outreach activities at Yale University under the mentorship of Dr. Bhart-Anjan S. Bhullar. Convergent evolution, or the independent derivation of similar features, as observed in the fossil record is arguably the greatest evidence of evolution by natural selection. However, how and why convergent evolution has happened is often poorly characterized. One striking, and understudied, example of convergent evolution is that of the secondary palate in amniotes (reptiles, mammals, and birds), which completely restructures the roof of the mouth and affects both feeding and breathing. This project will integrate analyses of the fossil record and developmental processes, to understand the timing and pattern of palate evolution and increase our understanding of the mechanisms driving the important phenomenon of convergent evolution. This project is an ideal platform for the mentorship of students, the development of classroom and public lectures, and outreach and education about the fossil record and developmental mechanisms of evolutionary change. 

Living amniotes and their extinct relatives in the fossil record display an astounding array of palate specializations, reflecting over 300 million years of evolutionary specialization in anatomy, diet, and behavior. Ancestrally the amniote palate allows the nasal passage to open into the mouth anteriorly, but mammals, crocodilians, and some lizards and turtles have independently derived an ossified secondary palate that segregates respiratory and olfactory functions from food acquisition and processing. This project will use quantitative analysis of the fossil record and modern evolutionary modeling with state-of-the-art imaging of embryonic anatomy in 3D to address two major research questions: 1) how has amniote palate shape evolved and secondary palate convergence been achieved? and 2) how has palate development changed to allow secondary palate convergence? By studying palate shape change at two distinct scales, macroevolutionary and developmental, the results of this project will reveal insights into the fundamental developmental and evolutionary mechanism that underlie the phenomenon of convergent evolution. Dr. Morris will develop educational materials for undergraduate and graduate students as well as public outreach activities through the Yale Peabody Museum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Extant amniotes - living mammals, birds, and 'reptiles' - display a spectacular diversity of anatomical, ecological, social, and reproductive specializations acquired during more than 320 million years of evolutionary divergence. Although it may be relatively trivial to distinguish the skulls of living mammals, birds, crocodylians, turtles, lizards, and snakes, detailed comparisons and analyses of the fossil record present intriguing parallel trends and convergent similarities in the amniote skull. Convergent evolution, or the independent derivation of similar features, is often cited as the greatest evidence of evolution by natural selection. By studying such natural experiments, the environmental factors driving selection and the changes to embryonic development which create evolutionary changes can be better understood. This project investigates the evolutionary and developmental origins of a striking case of convergent evolution in amniotes: the expansion of the palate and formation of 'secondary palates'.

The palate lies at a critical interface, with the skeleton and associated soft-tissues forming both the floor of the nasal passage and the roof of the mouth. Among the earliest evolving amniotes, the palate allowed the nasal passage to open into the front of the mouth. However, mammals, crocodylians, and some lizards and turtles have independently evolved expanded secondary palatal processes or 'secondary palates' which more fully segregate respiratory and olfactory functions from food acquisition and processing. Further, the fossil record of mammals and crocodylians include transitional forms which are also surprisingly similar, potentially indicating evolutionary or developmental constraint as a factor in the origin of these convergent similarities. However, it remains unclear precisely how convergently similar amniote palates have become or what changes to embryonic development enabled the evolution of 'secondary palates'. By working across macroevolutionary and developmental scales, this project quantifies major evolutionary patterns and assesses key developmental mechanisms for the convergent evolution of this complex anatomical feature.

To understand the pattern of divergence and convergence during amniote palate evolution, we collected CT scans and digitally segmented the individual skeletal elements of the palate for a comprehensive sample of all modern lineages and their extinct relatives. Our dataset captures the major palate conditions, including all 'secondary palates', and is the largest fully 3D dataset of comparative amniote cranial anatomy. Quantitative analyses of the shape of individual bones and the connections across the palate skeleton demonstrated that amniotes have evolved a tremendous range of modifications which reflect divergences in respiratory, olfactory, and dietary ecology. However, these data also revealed that crocodylians and mammals possess significantly more convergent 'secondary palates' than other clades.

Given the remarkable variation in palate anatomy and striking evolutionary convergence, we next investigated the embryonic origins of amniote palate diversity. In addition to microCT scans of embryonic series for representative species, we explored the initial differentiation and early morphogenesis of the palatal shelf. We captured the 3D shape of the developing palate, identified zones of proliferation (growth and replication of cells), and traced the differentiation of cartilage, bone, and other tissue types using high-resolution volumetric confocal microscopy. The assays for labeling key markers and the modified CLARITY protocol used to render tissues translucent were specially developed during this project for analyses of non-model 'reptiles', mammals, and birds. These volumetric datasets revealed that many features of the palate skeleton are pre-formed in the un-differentiated tissue precursors and enable the first direct comparisons of skeletal anatomy to the 3D shape of pre-skeletal tissues. On-going analyses explore the ontogenetic and evolutionary patterns of pre-skeletal morphogenesis across amniotes based on high-density surface landmarks.

This project has dramatically increased the total volumetric data of palate anatomy that has been quantitatively analyzed in a comparative framework. Manuscripts detailing the anatomical trends in palate evolution and the embryonic origins of the palate have already been prepared for submission, with a third exploring the molecular and cellular origins of palate diversity in preparation. The extensive 3D anatomical and embryological datasets collected for this project have been archived for additional study and will undoubtably serve as the basis of future research into the mechanisms underlying amniote skull evolution. Additionally, this fellowship supported Dr. Morris while preparing several manuscripts which have already been published, are in review, and will be submitted shortly. During this project, Dr. Morris also gained invaluable experience mentoring graduate and undergraduate students and translating discoveries into course materials targeting students from elementary school to university. New methods to study the molecular and cellular processes operating during early development will be made available to other researchers and shared in forthcoming publications. Finally, components of this project have already been included in displays in the newly renovated Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History. The insights into evolutionary phenomena will continue to inform future education programs at the museum and enable modules on convergent evolution and the scientific process.

Images (1 of )
  • This comparison shows the formation, outgrowth, and final size of the palatal shelf (PS) in representative lizards, crocodylians, birds, and mammals. Although geckos retain small PS, all other groups show extensive outgrowth, with alligator and mouse both fusing to form full 'secondary palates."
    Zachary S. Morris collected images of gecko, alligator, and chicken developmental stages. Mouse data modified from JO Bush & R Jiang. (2012) Development.

    Amniote Palate Morphogenesis
  • Comparison of the palate reveals the disparity of living lizards, including two evolutions of expanded vomers (yellow) and palatines (teal) which fully encircle the nasal passage. Ventral views of the whole and partial palates are shown above the palatine in ventral and posterior views.
